paragraphs.text:
%md 
# Spark and Machine Learning
From Spark East 2015, [video][1] and [slides][2]

[1]:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oTOgaMZkBKQ
[2]:http://www.slideshare.net/ksankar/data-science-with-spark

## Terms
[L1 and L2 regularization](http://www.quora.com/What-is-the-difference-between-L1-and-L2-regularization)
[RandomForestModel](http://www.quora.com/Random-Forests/How-do-random-forests-work-in-laymans-terms)
[Eigenvector and Eigenvalues](http://math.stackexchange.com/questions/23312/what-is-the-importance-of-eigenvalues-eigenvectors)

Eigenvectors make understanding linear transformations easy. They are the "axes" (directions) along which a linear transformation acts simply by "stretching/compressing" and/or "flipping"; eigenvalues give you the factors by which this compression occurs.

The more directions you have along which you understand the behavior of a linear transformation, the easier it is to understand the linear transformation; so you want to have as many linearly independent eigenvectors as possible associated to a single linear transformation. ... click above link for more.

result.msg:
Spark and Machine Learning

From Spark East 2015, video and slides

Terms

L1 and L2 regularization
RandomForestModel
Eigenvector and Eigenvalues

Eigenvectors make understanding linear transformations easy. They are the “axes” (directions) along which a linear transformation acts simply by “stretching/compressing” and/or “flipping”; eigenvalues give you the factors by which this compression occurs.

The more directions you have along which you understand the behavior of a linear transformation, the easier it is to understand the linear transformation; so you want to have as many linearly independent eigenvectors as possible associated to a single linear transformation. … click above link for more.

paragraphs.text:
%md
##Linear Regression
[wikipedia]:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_regression

### Difference between Linear Regression and Logistic Regression

From [quora]: 
* Linear regression uses the general linear equation Y=b0+∑(biXi)+ϵ where Y is a continuous dependent variable and independent variables Xi are usually continuous (but can also be binary, e.g. when the linear model is used in a t-test) or other discrete domains. ϵ is a term for the variance that is not explained by the model and is usually just called "error". Individual dependent values denoted by Yj can be solved by modifying the equation a little: Yj=b0+∑(biXij)+ϵj

* Logistic regression is another generalized linear model (GLM) procedure using the same basic formula, but instead of the continuous Y, it is regressing for the probability of a categorical outcome. In simplest form, this means that we're considering just one outcome variable and two states of that variable- either 0 or 1.


[stackexchange]:http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/29325/what-is-the-difference-between-linear-regression-and-logistic-regression)
[quora]:http://www.quora.com/Whats-the-relationship-between-linear-and-logistic-regression

result.msg:
Linear Regression

Difference between Linear Regression and Logistic Regression

From quora:

  • Linear regression uses the general linear equation Y=b0+∑(biXi)+ϵ where Y is a continuous dependent variable and independent variables Xi are usually continuous (but can also be binary, e.g. when the linear model is used in a t-test) or other discrete domains. ϵ is a term for the variance that is not explained by the model and is usually just called “error”. Individual dependent values denoted by Yj can be solved by modifying the equation a little: Yj=b0+∑(biXij)+ϵj

  • Logistic regression is another generalized linear model (GLM) procedure using the same basic formula, but instead of the continuous Y, it is regressing for the probability of a categorical outcome. In simplest form, this means that we're considering just one outcome variable and two states of that variable- either 0 or 1.
